  >=

  > Members of the list have rightly been sceptical of my find as it is 
 =
 > almost
  > unheard of in the West, if I had not seen it myself I would n=
ot have
  > believed it either. I have seen many swords with Muromachi/Momo=
yama style
  > koshirae over the years, but 99.9% have been 19th c. swords =
in retro 
  > style.
  > Two exceptions come to mind: Victor Harris and I c=
atalogued the blades in
  > the Museum of Japanese Sword Fittings in Tokyo =
for Christie's in '05. In
  > that collection was a Momoyama tachi koshirae=
 that was later sold in 
  > NY, the
  > other was an itomaki tachi made fo=
r an Ikeda Daimyo in Christie's London.
  > Victor has seen this nagamaki a=
nd agrees that it is 16th c.
  >
  > I think this weapon is the first of a =
number of identical contract pieces
  > for an armoury, as it is numbered '=
1' as are one seppa, the fuchi and the
  > tsuka in ink under the fuchi, it=
 is utilitarian, with thin yamagane 
  > mounts
  > and low quality lacquer=
, the nakago-ana are not well made. The long ububa
  > can be accounted for=
 by its lack of use, it may have been polished 
  > only once
  > or twice =
then stored for a very long time, this would account for its 
  > fairly
  =
> good condition apart from the leather tsuka binding shrinking and being
 =
 > attacked by insects.
  >
  > It may look like a sword but it has the thi=
ck saya of a polearm, no 
  > kurikata
  > and the tsuka is 21.5" long.
  >=

  > As I stated in my earlier post it weighs around 6lbs, this is not 
  >=
 something
  > one would want as a personal weapon, it is too heavy and awk=
ward to carry
  > and I think would only be useful in battle.
